Topic.Title: Barrons on AAPL; Sundal Collier says "Sell", target $400, "cycle of vogue" ending....

Message.Msg: 'ibex' is somebody who supposedly lives in NJ, but he knows the geographic in and outs of silicon valley. 'ibex' only posts by cut and paste and hurls personal insults, but he will never ever reply with reasoning, cause this is personal thinking. 'ibex' supposedly successfully invested in qcom, but as you have found out, he knows nothing about qcom's LTE. 'ibex' supposedly successfully invested in brcm too, but his knowledge of brcm's baseband is exactly 180 degress diffeerent from what brcm is doing. but 'ibex' offers you a mirror of what is actually going on inside nvda. eg. he might insinuate this and that with cut and paste, but he will never ever go out and say directly what nvda is going to do in the future. In the rare occasions that he slips, you can take it to the bank that is the gospel truth. like when dreamers says nvda might benefit when txn got out and I said amzn is only about cheap and samsung will probably get it for fab fills, ibex stayed totally silent. then he posts that amzn going mediatek. You can bank on that being the truth, nvda is NOT in the running for the amzn socket. eg. he offers a picture of the environment inside nvda right now. Jen has so misguided the whole Tegra program, they are so way late on A15, nvda is really out of the picture now. So instead of spending his time singing his own glorifications, Jen simmers and hurls venomous barbs at all his successful mobile competitors, real or imaginary. Hence ibex's lack of +ve nvda posts and posts nothing but insults at the likes of aapl, samsung, qcom. Jen is getting so irrelevant in the app space, Jen even will hurt insults at potential customers like hp or dell. Tegra failed, just fold it. nvda can't even string ARM cores together, and there are fools here who drank so much koolaid, they still expect nvda to out-ARM ARM in processor designs. 100M$ loss in tegra this Q, nothing in the product pipe for the whole of 2013. care to take a guess how big the loses will be at the end of 2013? In silicon, no chips, no talk.

Topic.Title: more sellers

Message.Msg: That's perfectly fine - selling covered calls to greedy people, not unlike shorts, lowers my cost basis. Sold calls and bought puts on the pre 10:15 am pop and now I am in at less than 11.50. A lot less risk using this strategy albeit it does limit your upside potential some - but who cares it's trading sideways right now with plenty of support above it's 52 week low. I see little downside risk right now and considering; 1.trading at a respectable 15 PE (lower than the industry average). 2. Increasing revenues and margins in all major product lines, 3. soon to be the only high-end GPU desktop provider (once AMD divests it's assets) and possibly consoles. 4 exception levered free cash flow 5. Half of its market cap in cash and growing 6. Diversified product portfolio with superior brand recognition 7. Emerging competitor in the mobile market 8. Leader in cloud based GPU initiatives. There is a lot of upside potential! Now that being said I do agree the chart stinks but who cares the best long term strategy are to buy great companies as low as you can and sell them as high as you can. Sorry shorty, there really isn't a ton of downside here right now other than a #$%$ chart and once the chart starts to look good that is when all the retail suckers would have bough on hype and it's time to sell.

I so wanted to be long this stock. After digging into the underlying facts I see this company facing many headwinds. I am sure you are frustrated with NVDA underperformance but can't come to grips with it and keep lashing out at people who may suggest otherwise. I hardly ever post on message board of stocks that I have conviction long on, whats the point? so - I hope your NVDA long position makes you tons of money. I am going to keep swing trading it for now. I don't see any point in getting big time behind this stock with so many challenges and macro uncertainty. good luck to you

Topic.Title: more sellers

Message.Msg: 1 year price target is $15 , that puts NVIDIA at respectable industry average trailing PE. Now - assuming revenues stay flat as well as margins, in the upcoming year which btw is simply not going to happen; with 3.5 billion in cash and growing, at WORST, this stock loses 5 bucks (which can mitigated by option play) it would be trading at 7x current PE and less than book. So, near to medium term with the same but MORE likely 50% upside potential I just can't see why you'd be short considering it could go a lot higher than 15 - dumb move in my opinion.

Topic.Title: more sellers

Message.Msg: Well, I appreciate your backdoor niceties but I am not a perma-bull at this point nor am I lashing out due to poor performance - I simply want to join in on the fun. Honestly, I just bought in, when the stock dropped recently and as I do see there are headwinds facing NVIDIA, I believe these headwinds are not isolated to NVIDIA alone. So, do you care to share your perspective on negative forces and their impact NVIDIA? As I see it they are a well branded, decently managed company with a diversified portfolio, growing revenue and income, a great balance sheet, who has expanded into growth markets which is ripe for the taking. There are many on this board who post exaggerated downside perspective none of which is empirical but rather conjecture at best if not an out right lies.

Topic.Title: more sellers

Message.Msg: I am not currently short but due to my negative sentiment and reading charts, I am making money shorting any spike-up, I have been regularly posting my positions. Btw, I am in this just to make money - if I thought NVDA was near bottom I would go long. I have seen action in the last month. NVDA sells of harder than market and underperforms market on recovery. Some of this has to do with semi sector, most of it has to do with NVDA. I still think single digits are possible when weak hands are shaken. That would be a time I would consider going long. Also, most other weak performing companies have cut expenses and had lay-offs. AMD, TXN. I dont think NVDA operating expenses justify the declining revenue stream they are supporting.

Topic.Title: more sellers

Message.Msg: well, I am not going to regurgitate the whole litany of reasons. You can see some of the past postings. NVDA has a great balance sheet which tends to cloud judgement. NVDA gets its lions share of revenue from PC market. There are double negatives in this market for NVDA: 1. PC market is declining 2. NVDA is being designed out by integrated solutions from INTC and AMD NVDA is OK in the high-end GPU market but you can count on competitors and challengers. NVDA has become the King of FUD in mobile market. They over-promise and under-deliver. You can see the story on Tegra-2, Tegra-3, Denver etc. They seem to be trying to correct their behavior as they have been quiet so far on Wayne and Grey. It may also be that the projects are in bad shape and hence CEO's reluctance to opine on the subject (see how quickly the last analyst call ended when the subject came up). Meanwhile, Nvidia mobile head Mike Rayfield recently quit the company (not a good sign) and so has Icera head Stan Boland. Remember the competition in Mobility is intense, QCOM, BRCM, Mediatek etc. are the clear leaders. 2nd Tier like TXN, FSL are getting out. 3rd Tier like NVDA and MRVL need to either get big or, get out.

Topic.Title: more sellers

Message.Msg: O - I guess I simply don't understand most of your comments and essentially where you are getting your information from. As I said before, in my prior post, when the fundamentals and charts show strong support at or around your short target I am not sure how you justify or mitigate the risk for such little gain. The beta is 1.8 which is not flat by any means but it seems to me there are many other higher beta stocks out there that would contribute to a better risk/reward outcome. You say it is possible to go to single digits - yeah just like it is possible it will go to 15 but less likely, again as I said before. In fact I believe you yourself said that you covered at 11.80 right, so how do you think that at its current price it has not bottomed - please explain? Why would you cover if you truly believed there was little risk in holding till single digits? I think I have the answer and, despite you WANTING it to go down, you see they same fundamentals regarding price and valuation I have have mentioned prior and aren't willing to take the risk. Now on to some of the fundamentals; 1. "Also, most other weak performing companies have cut expenses and had lay-offs. AMD, TXN" Ahh yeah but neither of those are NVIDIA - NVIDIA is growing and hiring...so not sure what your point is here and I hope you AREN'T extrapolating the the current conditions of poor performing companies in the industry and deriving that NVIDIA will have the same fate - that is an opinion non of which is based in fact and if anything is a reason to buy NVIDIA as they will likely benefit from industry consolidation via attrition. 2. "I dont think NVDA operating expenses justify the declining revenue stream they are supporting." Again, can you please post numbers or statements to support your claims. I really am having a hard time understanding this statement as revenues have increased in almost all segments not near end of life as well as their margins. Have you read any of their investor literature or the quarterly's? Like I said before it is statements like that I seem to be compelled to respond to- mostly because they are posting an inaccurate picture in order to justify a position - feel free to respond. Thanks and Happy Holidays. :-)

Topic.Title: more sellers

Message.Msg: 1. PC market is declining Yes, I agree but mostly for consumer based segment. The PC market will shrink but the highend gaming market is stable and growing some both of which are high margin, and the mainstay of NVIDIA's GPU sales. 2. NVDA is being designed out by integrated solutions from INTC and AMD. This is not true and in fact it is quite the contrary. INTC and AMD both have solutions but market segments where they have a foothold (one which is declining) is a different than the market segment NVIDIA reaches. NVIDIA is poised to take the remainder of the high end market from AMD as AMD becomes further burdened, by cash flow issues, brain drain, and poor product recognition - NVIDIA is way better branded and much more developer-centeric. They have outperformed AMD despite AMD having comparable, possibly better, and new GPU technology - kepler will change that. 3. NVDA has become the King of FUD in mobile market. They over-promise and under-deliver. Not sure how growing revenues by almost 50% yoy is under performing. If you are solely commenting on the perceived performance of their chips let me say this; despite having the perception that they have an inferior product, which I agree is outdated, they keep getting wins and growing revenues in this segment - again brand recognition and loyalty often outweigh other intangibles and to be honest by all standards their mobile products are still quite good despite needing an upgrade which we will see this year. They have a proven track record of innovating and setting the bar for performance and with the amount they are set to spend on R&D I have no reason to believe that trend won't continue. Their are all but a few players left in the mobile space and their is plenty of opportunity for NVIDIA to gain more market share, improve their margins (which includes going to smaller footprint) and be on track for a higher profits.

Topic.Title: JUST IN from iSuppl: global semiconductor market shares ranking, top 20

Message.Msg: Best has read the rest. And what is clear is what an irrelevant rounding-error nvidia really is. In the Global Semiconductor Industry. Get out your magnifying glasses, boys, and take a look. 1 __ Intel ______ $47,543 Billion in 2012 Semiconductor Revenues 2 __ Samsung ___ $30,474 3 __ Qualcomm __ $12,976 4 __ Texas Inst __ $12,008 5 __ Toshiba ____ $10,996 9 __ Broadcom ___ $7,940 15 __ nvidia _____ $3,823 nvidia has just 1.3% of the Global Semiconductor Market. Ha ha ha ha! "We're the Global Leader in this and that don't u know." With a mini-scule 1.3% of the Global Market. What a bunch of pathetic carnival barkers.

Topic.Title: JUST IN from iSuppl: global semiconductor market shares ranking, top 20

Message.Msg: "__ nvidia _____ $3,823" They are still highly profitable, so who cares? I really don't see your point. Does the company state publicly that they are the global leader in semi revenue? I certainly never heard that. Additionally, you'd be stupid to buy a company solely based on gross revenues as compared to it's competitors or the industry. Where it ranks in distribution or revenue has little to do with the companies performance or future growth potential. I agree the top four controlling a 100 million is huge but that is just more lunch for Nvidia to eat in the coming years - keep in mind revenues, profits, margins and market share is indeed growing, so again I don't see your point.

Topic.Title: JUST IN from iSuppl: global semiconductor market shares ranking, top 20

Message.Msg: What is clear is IF nvidia Doubled in size, -- Yes, 100% growth in semiconductor revenues -- they Still would not make it to the #9th smallest. Up from #15th smallest today. And being the #9 smallest in a 5 company industry is no where to be investing your hard-earned cash. Face it -- She's nothing but a rounding-error, boys. 1.3% of the Global Market. Ha ha ha ha!
